text: [Applause] okay thank you um so I'm going to talk a
little bit today about my journey and others that I've spoken to recently
about the Journey of leadership to firsttime parent to working parent um we talk a lot
about diversity and inclusion in our industry at the moment um and part of
that is obiously women in leadership roles so I myself am a new mom I've been
back in the workforce for 5 months uh attempting to work part-time that's definitely an interesting uh journey and
definitely a large juggle but I feel like I have a unique opportunity as one of the very few women in it in Melbourne
to talk about this journey and to talk about how you guys as the fellow leadership of our industry can help make
this a little bit easier and to help hopefully make sure that more women a
stay in our industry and B come back to work from having children so just as a show of hands um
who in the room has kids great and who in the room carried a
child and gave birth to a child there are three including me that's four um so
as you can tell we do have a challenge um having a baby in a leadership role
isn't the easiest thing um in fact was much harder than I ever anticipated it
being um so I've started to talk about my journey since coming back to work and it's surprising how many people want to
talk about this um but don't have a forum to talk about it and are really scared nervous anxious to talk about it
so hopefully I can start the trend and we can make this a little bit easier it's not really big things that
need to change it's lot lots of little things these things don't need large HR policy changes they don't need um you
know lots of thought and documentation it's the small things that you guys as Leaders can do and to coach and Mentor
your leadership team to make this a bit easier this is all about humans real
life and emotions so the talk I'm going to do is
broken up into four sections pre-pregnancy because that's a thing we don't talk about um being pregnant being
our mat or parental leave if you're a dad and coming back to work so let's
kick off with pre-pregnancy anxiety uh this is a topic that people
don't like to talk about but it's the reality of women um who are thinking
about having children um many of you are working with women that are coming up the ranks I
guarantee you there's anxiety in how they're thinking about becoming a mom I
myself and many others I know had to to seek professional assistance from a counselor to get myself over the line to
have a child not because I was worried about being a mom it's because I was worried
about what would happen to me as a professional in a male dominated
industry um anxiety is referred to in our culture and society as a mental
health condition but really it's about emotional health a lot of people for
many reasons have anxiety um and they don't SE help because it's a mental health condition
and that's a really bad word in our society it affects people's insurance premiums um people you know it's it's
expensive these things in my opinion have to change and we have to start talking about the fact that these things
are part of life um you come to work for a little bit but that's not your entire life it's it's a part of who you are as
a human education so there's very little
education out there about what it's like to become a working mom or a working
parent um part of that is US starting to talk about and some of us being a bit Brave to to do that but um what can your
companies do to help lift the lid on this how can you get your colleagues
talking about it how can you yourself talk about your personal Journey that may not have been as smooth sailing as
everybody around you thinks it was financial planning so a big part of
female leaders in this organization is most of us are the main income earner
for our families so you guys as uh males um when you have a baby you could take a
couple of weeks off work maybe maybe some a couple of months but we have to take at least six months off work some
some less but um most of them take on average about 6 months off work and being the main income earner of your
family that takes a pretty big hit on your budget so um also most women in
these leadership roles um earn a certain amount that the government doesn't help you with anything no money nothing so
you have to think about this in advance I started planning financially to have a child two years before I even started to
to try and have a baby so um these are all the things that are on the women that you're working around they're on
their minds um it's on their minds and and we need to start talking about it because they need someone to talk to um
and we want to try and make sure that women can take on leadership roles and still go through all of these
things IVF um you'll be surprised how many people around you are going through IVF it's very common this day and age as
yes oh oh sorry I thought you asking a question um as we all have children a
little bit later in life um this is actually more real than most people realize
um it's uh it's fraught with fear it's Frau with emotion it's lonely most
people going through IVF in the workforce are very disconnected from their employment because all that's on their mind is the fact that they're
going through IVF um it's something that most leaders struggle to to counter when someone says
to you one of your team members says oh I'm going through IVF just have to think about how would you respond to that
would you even know what to say would you know how to help them probably not so how can we do some education in our
industry to try and make this a little bit safer for people to talk about I'm going to read you a little
story from someone in our industry today very well known um who's currently going
through IVF just to kind of explain the impact this has it's interesting that all the
flexible working features and encouragement around the journey are all for post
pregnancy like it happens by Magic and then you get all these amazing benefits and support in the wonderful journey of
Parenthood this is a minimal consideration for life before being pregnant then you decide to start trying
if you're lucky enough something happens and you head down the path it's neatly laid out as a normal
pregnancy what happens when you miscarry the grief gets hidden away and
you walk through the doors at work each day like nothing's happened as a female I'm really
conscious about staying strong and staying connected working hard to make
sure I can climb the ladder so I need to keep it together I wasn't even able to
use my bement leave when I had a miscarriage but yet my child
died then we had to head down the path of fertility treatment which you don't talk about is
because it's a roller coaster of emotions you worry about the impacts of work you worry about how your peers will
respond then you got to take these random days off work for medical procedures hormone injections and your
hormones are going crazy if you're lucky you get to move down the path of pregnancy and hope that it's normal hope
that that you don't Mis carry again and have to start all over again like nothing's happened or you can try try
try and try again each time costing you emotions not to mention the $10,000
every time every round is another round of grief that you bury and pretend everything is okay but in reality it's
all you're thinking about and every waking minute while you're at work you're thinking about it but no one
around you has any idea and if an ends up like me not me
this person um the grief and grief bubbles away in the background meanwhile
working and not letting letting it impact your results and your team but in reality it does and most of the time
it's immediately considered as you not being able to handle the pressures of your job I didn't feel safe to share any of
this with my manager or my colleague due to the fear of treating me differently and them not understanding what I was
going through I don't I didn't want to explain it over and over and over over again and then there's the adoption
process and the Judgment I experienced when I did attempt to share this with two of my
colleagues so this is just one person of many going through this around you um
and they people don't currently feel safe to talk about this so what are some other things we
can think about um a buddy program there's people in your organization who are planning to have a family it's it's
a fact of life um how can you think about getting a buddy program up and going in a confidential manner um where
people can feel safe to talk about it because there are people going through this right around you
today what about buying some extra extra annual leave a lot of companies these days have policies to buy extra anual
leave but it's pretty much normally capped at 20 days for someone who's considering a family who especially is a
female who is the main income owner for the family is this an option that you could consider with your within your
company we have to try and move this industry to allow us to be safe to talk about these
things it's not easy but um I I really believe and the many people I've spoken
to since coming back to work feel like their Journey would have been much easier had they been able to talk to
somebody so as I mentioned we've got to start talking about it okay so then for those that are lucky
enough uh people fall pregnant and then a whole new roller coaster starts it's a
secret for the first 12 months sorry for the first 12 weeks no one knows about it um
you're excited you're happy you're scared you're nervous but no one knows about it um I myself would have loved to
have shared it with my team but I was really conscious how would they respond would they treat me differently would I
be put wrapped around with cotton wool what if I lost the baby how would they handle the grief of me losing the child
all of those emotions exist uh within all the women that are going through this today not to mention the dads let's
not forget the Dad's going through this sickness some people get really really
sick um I was one of those people severe morning sickness severe all day sickness
um some of the things that go through your mind when you're going through um pregnancy and being this sick this is on
top of your job as a leader so you know most women are looking after multiple teams um some of the things they're
thinking about on top of their normal day I got to get to a meeting room first so can sit by the door so that if I need
to run out to be sick I can get out of the room without anything happening in the room right this is something that is
on people's minds um I can't go anywhere near the kitchen at lunchtime because the smells are going to make me sick but
then people are saying oh you don't want to socialize with your team no I really do but I really can't be in that kitchen
because it's not going to be pleasant for anyone um women normally bring multiple
changes of clothes to work um getting to and from work is a challenge those with really bad morning sickness can't go on
the train don't like motion so getting to work is a real challenge um those
that make it to work it's it's a pretty big achievement um for me for the first 12
weeks all I could eat was bananas I get to work and I've left the bananas at home my God what am I going to eat all
day I'm just going to be sick more sick I got to go find some bananas right like for other people it's chips or chocolate
or whatever it is but for me days without those bananas they weren't good days um and all the team events that we
hold to ensure our culture and you know all that teams are happy most of them resolve around
food um so pizzas um going out for burgers and chips or going out for a
drink at the pub all these things that pregnant women suffering from severe morning sickness can't
do restructures are a fact of life in our industry um but someone who's
pregnant and you announce a restructure do you spend more time with them to talk through this um it's it's way more
emotional for someone who's about to go on a long period of time off work that the work that they're coming back to is
probably going to change so think about how you could spend a little bit more time with someone going through
this interviewing um we really want to encourage women not to put their careers on hold but going through an interview
when you're heavily pregnant and your emotions are charged and you're suffering from severe morning sickness
that's a lot um so how do we make that environment a little bit easier how do we coach the people that are doing the
interview to adapt their interview techniques to make it a little bit easier for people to um be successful in
that environment some women might end up in tears in the interview how would you as an interviewer cope with that how
would your team cope with that um unconscious bias training is a
really good thing that's been happening in our industry um typically though it's a 4-Hour Workshop people leave it
and nothing happens um you'll be very surprised if I told you some of the real stories of
things that were said to me during my pregnancy at work um it might be 2018 but didn't feel like it so we I think
continuing to talk about these things and being honest about the truth about what happens in the workforce when
you're pregnant um is really important expecting parents uh let's
have a support group for them it's not just the m s what about the dads they're about their wife's about to go through
um or or um yeah their wife's about to go through a a pretty intense time
giving birth and becoming a new mom what about the dads like it's scary how do the dads in our environment have someone
to talk to so think about some networking groups flexible working uh most
companies these days haven't but does it really work um does flexible working just mean working from home it doesn't
it it means working on the train um you know not having to use your leave for your appointments that you and your
partner want to go to together um I'm surprised at how many stories I'm hearing about companies that require
people to use their annual leave to go to an appointment for a scan like in this day and age we've got to be better
and we've got to be more creative about flexible working fear it's it's real um fear of
being forgotten when you go on mat leave um fear of being left out fear of going backwards in your career I I again I
think talking about this is going to help um lift the lid but the fear drives a lot of the emotion in pregnant women
um I myself remember driving away from work on my last day Bing my eyes out in the car going oh my God no one's going
to remember who I am um in actual fact they did but it's the fear it's you know
it's not controllable it's sometimes a little irrational but it's there and we need to acknowledge that are going
through this and we want to help them come back to work so we need people to start talking about
this okay so maternity leave and parental leave if you're lucky enough to
be able to have some time off as a dad salary reviews so typically let's
say um a mom takes 12 months off work um there's going to be a salary review in that period do them before they go on
that leave it shouldn't be something that people should be thinking about while they're on mat leave they have enough to think about so have the
conversation manage the expectations before they go so they don't have to think about it while they're
off um expectations on return before they go on maternity leave be really
clear about what people are coming back to it might change that's okay but be really clear about what they're coming
back to write it down so that people have it written down they know what it is coming back to something that's just
completely unknown is extremely it it drives the emotion and drives the fear
um and and does mean for some women they just don't come back to work increased training and education so
um someone goes on maternity leave or um dads for a long period of time um why do
their training budgets have to stop why don't they increase because people aren't naturally learning in the natural
Workforce every day that we all just learn by osmosis so why aren't these actually slightly larger for those that
are off leave and trying and encour people to do further education or further training while they're
off um industry connection so um meetups going to a Meetup at 5:00 in the
afternoon with a child a newborn baby that's impossible um so how can you stay
connected to our industry um going to conferences with a child I tried it a few times not
successfully um you know let alone getting the pram in and out of the conference but having a screaming child
you know there are challenges and you'd be surprised the reaction um from an audience similar to this with a child
sitting on the corner um so how can we make our industry um enable the
connection for people that are off on a long period of of leave company events so they happen
while people are away it's again really hard to to attend these things with a newborn baby and not to mention you're
probably sleep deprived so could you got could the company off wear a babysitter or an
ananny for a couple of hours just so that they could come into the office or to the event just for one or two hours
to reconnect with their peers and their colleagues um that that one hour of
reconnection with um the professional environment with real humans you'll be
surprised the impact that has on a mom celebrate their Milestones just
because they're off doesn't mean we don't celebrate the normal things we would celebrate so when they have the
baby stick it in your calendar in three months time to give them a call and say hey how' the 12 month week needles go
and how are you going you made it to 12 weeks like that's a huge achievement your child's still alive and you and
your partner haven't broken up hopefully so like that's something we should celebrate um and then again at six
months you know like hey they're about to start some solids like engage with your staff who were off on leave um
interact with them on a human level it's not just about have I ticked the HR policy box did I talk to them at the
right times that H I want me to talk to them it's so much more than
that the child care transition so now we're starting to talk about you know
slowly coming back to work first day oh my God I got to put my child in child care someone else is going to look after
my kid the emotion so if you know that this is happening give them a call a couple of days later and ask them how it
went um you'll be surprised again the impact this has um something that was quite totally
unexpected for me was the Judgment when I came back to work that my child was in child care three days a week comments
such as oh but they're not one yet no they're not um why aren't they with your
mom my mom works um so again it's 2018
but here we are still having these kind of comments in the workforce today um staying connected so someone's
off on mat leave it's so much more than just one visit into the office um I remember when I first came into the
office um we took about 4 days of planning how am I going to get in there what time am I going to get in there when's the baby going to sleep um how am
I going to feed the baby in the office um all the people that I want to talk to going to be there at the right time is
really hard work um so maybe the team members you know once in once a month or
every couple of months could go out to the mom or dad and visit them at their place why do the new parents have to
always come into the office um it's really hard work so how about what we think about that being a two-way
street [Music] um uh what about a book club so lots of
lonely nights with a baby um you know could could a colleague um support this
person who's off on leave and and they could read a book together just as a reconnection point um just something to
talk to a professional about other than all the nappy
changing okay so um now the child's in child care yay um you got to come back
to work um becoming a working parent is tough I've been doing it for five months
um and I'm just surviving definitely wouldn't say I'm thriving um it's it's a
real juggle some of the things I think we should think about um communication
when someone's about to come back to work it shouldn't be a surprise um there are many stories where
people that I've heard where people come back to work and no one knew they were coming back walk into the office and oh
what are you doing here are you coming back imagine how that feels with someone who's been out of the office for 3
months 6 months 12 months like oh you didn't know what about the person that's doing your job oh they didn't know you
were coming back what does that mean for them this whole thing happens so communication it's very
important the changes at work so when they come back on their first day don't dump all that on them on the first day
that's way too much to take in um think about that transition plan and think about how you can do that over time
maybe you could have lunch with them a couple of days before like make that a slower transition than first day here's
everything that's changed good luck back to work you go um it's just too
much um this is something that I reflect on my time that I wish I had it done I'm stepping back into a really fast-paced
delivery team with over 50 people um on my you know within the first week of coming back I I missed out on
reconnecting with my peers some of them I still haven't had a coffee with 5 months later um I wish I had have said
actually you know what I'm going to take a month to reconnect with the business reconnect with my peers reconnect with
the with the team and then I'll take on the actual accountability and responsibility of my job um today I'm
trying to do both of those things and the perception is oh tny doesn't have time for me or Tenny doesn't want to
talk to me that's not true just trying to survive um so on hindsight I wish I
had have said actually I think I'll take a couple of weeks or a month to just reconnect and and work out how to do
this working parent thing um getting to and from work I
don't know where you all live but um I'm on the lillow line and trying to get a car park after 7:00 is
impossible um so trying to get to work trying to get the little one Harrison to to daycare um things go wrong poo
explosions vomiting traffic all you can you can name it right it happens but if
I don't get him dropped off into the the car park by 7:00 we work I work in Richmond I can't get to work so um what
could you do to help help help a returning parent if you've got car car spaces could you offer them up for a
month just to help them settle in um is it is it really that much to ask to give give your staff a car park for a couple
of weeks um could you help the finances of a if you don't have the car Parks available of a car park that's close by
so just those tiny little things make a really big difference to a new working parent
um as I mentioned before our Meetup culture does not support um new working
parents um and um a lot of people coming back to the industry really struggle to
reconnect and Rec and do the networking thing um so how do we change our Meetup
culture as an industry can we do every second one as a daytime thing instead of a nighttime thing um maybe we'll get
more women turning up to those events um if they're during the day if we've got true flexible working hours
you know I could go to a meet up during the day and finish off those rest of the hours for the office at home once
Harrison's asleep so how can we shift these things to make it more inclusive for all types of
people extra sck leave um this has been one of the hardest things for me um I
think Harrison's been sick more than not um since going to daycare those daycare bugs are deadly and I actually get more

income owner of my family I'm conscious that oh I'm going to use up on my sickly probably in the first month of coming
back to work um but I'm sick because he made me sick it's a fact of life so
could you um provide some extra sickly for new parents in the first six months just to alleviate some of that
stress life integration we talk a little bit about work life balance I I don't think that's a thing um it's about
integration so how do you um how do you how do you get those two things working well together how do we really be
flexible um for me I work a shorter um day in the office I am lucky enough to
have a great manager who allows me to include my time on the train as work time because I can actually be really
productive on the train I You' be surprised how many slack messages you can respond to on the train so um that's
part of my workday and that means I can go and get Harrison by 4:00 and spend a little bit of time with him in the
evening before I have to do the nighttime routine and then put him to bed so um that true integration of life
and and technology is allowing us to make this easier and easier so be
creative Mother's group so um for those of you that haven't had kids um you get
a Mother's group from the government that you join and you may or may not like them but in my case I did um but
now I'm back at work and they're not so now I'm going to miss out on that and
they're really the people that are probably going to keep me sane so how do I stay connected to my mother's group
they meet up during the day they go to um Child Care play centers but I'm at work that's not going to work again
flexible working means that you know I can go see them in the morning I can work from home in the afternoon and I
don't have to miss out um it might sound something really small but being able to continue to have those moms to talk to
at 2:00 in the morning when Harrison's not sleeping is a
lifesaver breastfeed ing okay maybe the more sensitive one um so as a
breastfeeding Mom I'm lucky enough to be able to do that I was not prepared for
how this would work with work um and not prepared for how awkward this would be to talk about at work um breastfeeding
in public didn't even notice it breastfeeding and talking about at work
whoa um that was weird and awkward and and still is to some extent um it's very
emotional um but it's for some women they're really lucky to be able to breastfeed and um but working in
breastfeeding is difficult um breastfeeding at a conference that's interesting um what if Harrison's in
daycare and I'm still feeding but I need to express when do I do that at a conference uh that's interesting um
these are all things that are going on with moms trying to get back to work and trying to stay connected as a professional trying to climb the ladder
um continue to be a leader in the industry but they've got all these things to think about
um a lot of organizations these days have quiet rooms or mom's rooms um we've
got one um but yet I've used it once because every time I go to use it
someone's in there eating their lunch doing yoga watching TV someone took the power cable so now I don't have any
power um all of these things happen and and for those of you that again
education um if you're expressing at work it's something that you need to do at an exact moment of time um or things
don't quite go well so what do you do if you can't get access to a room got to go and try it in your car on the toilet
seat like it's not very pleasant so how is your environment a work set up to
enable women to be able to come back to work whilst continuing to be able to do something that is um a connection to
their child and um something that some women are really lucky to be able to do um say no to social events CU I don't
want to go to the pub CU I can't drink beer cuz I'm breastfeeding oh but you don't want to socialize no but I can
drink s Sprite or Coke it's okay oh but you don't want to have a beer with us oh no because I'm breastfeeding um I was
not prepared for that kind of conversation and didn't even think it would be something I would have to be trying to explain and justify to
people um breastfeeding is the single hardest thing I have ever done in my life I had a really rough pregnancy but
breastfeeding was even harder than I ever expected it to be the lack of education and the lack of integration
back into work and the understanding of what it is some of the comments I got I was not prepared for it at all so I
would like to try and fix this and um eight eight of the women I've spoken to
since coming back from work stopped breastfeeding their child because they couldn't Express at
work um it's a gift to be able to do that and it's great for a child to be able to do it but eight women Just In My
Time coming back had to stop breastfeeding their child because they couldn't Express a work so just have a
think about that um okay real support from peers so
the general comment of oh how are you going um actually if I really replied to that answer how would they be able to
respond would they be prepared for the truth um how are you setting up our leaders and our colleagues to actually
be able to respond to someone that says actually I'm I'm not I'm really not Co um and and how can you help them as as
peers uh the guilt that's a thing um probably forever um The Mummy guilt oh
he's a daycare um and the professional guilt oh I got to go home and grab him or actually today's my day off and I'm
going to spend it with Harrison and I'm not going to respond to anyone on slack um juggling both of those things um is
difficult and the guilt is a thing and I encourage you to talk to women um about this who who are moms or who are
thinking about becoming moms because it does Drive the anxiety that I talked about at the start and it does mean why
a lot of women end up with post Nal depression or they don't have a second child or um their relationship at home
struggles with their partner so it's something we have to talk about and then there's those dreaded
calls from daycare wh Harrison's falling over and he's hit his head you got to come get in be here in an hour okay I
remember my first one of these I was actually um second week back at work I had a meeting with our new GM of
engineering I'm walking into the room and my phone rings and it's the daycare Sor I just going to answer this pick up
the phone you need to come get him to the newer GM of engineering it's my first meeting with him he doesn't know
who I am oh God what am I going to do so um it's again something on people's
minds that are coming back to work it's a whole another layer of something to think
about so becoming a working parent is much much much more than parental leave and maternity leave
we need to think about the human interactions And the emotions and we need more people to start talking about
this to make it easier for everyone that's my little boy um my husband's
British so and yeah thanks for listening to my talk that's my little
